Award.AwardTitle: Heme protein catalysis and the biocoordination chemistry of HNO
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program supports work by Professor Patrick Farmer at Baylor University on biological NOx catalysis, with a recent focus on the generation and reactivity of nitroxyl (HNO) adducts of metalloproteins. NOx intermediates are involved in the catalytic cycles of enzymes that control nitrogen-based metabolism in plants and animals. Previous work has identified several distinct steps in reductive pathways, including the formation of metal-bound HNO intermediates. The Farmer lab has demonstrated that many ferrous heme proteins like myoglobin and hemoglobin trap free HNO efficiently to form stable HNO adducts. Like oxymyoglobin, these HNO complexes are low spin d6 and diamagnetic; they have been well characterized by different spectroscopic and analytical techniques, including nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), mass spectrometry (MS), and X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS). New projects continue the exploration of the bio-coordination chemistry of HNO, including new "nitroxyl" adducts of non-heme enzymes and model complexes. The enzyme quercetinase which utilizes O2 to chemically modify flavonols, has been shown to turnover in the presence of HNO, generating products that incorporate the atoms of nitroxyl. The combination of classical coordination chemistry, molecular biology and physical characterization techniques provides a wide breadth of training for both graduate and undergraduate students. A departmental NMR instrument will be upgraded for use in outreach to college students from smaller regional colleges through the Advanced Instrumentation Workshop, which hosted 22 students and 8 faculty members from 10 different schools in 2009, the majority from underrepresented groups.

The intent of this award is to address mechanistic aspects of metalloprotein reactivity from an inorganic perspective, i.e., the inorganic chemistry that underlies biological nitrogen-based metabolism. As HNO reacts with O2-binding proteins, Professor Farmer and his team hypothesize that it should form stable complexes with metal sites that are known to bind oxygen. This hypothesis has already led to identification of a previously unknown enzymatic reaction. Ultimately, these studies will have implications for the global effects of modern agriculture, based on understanding the chemical basis for the generation of non-carbon greenhouse gases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This work addresses mechanistic aspects of the inorganic chemistry that underlies biological reactive nitrogen species and nitrogen metabolism. We have reported extensively on the HNO adduct of ferrous myoglobin, HNO-Mb, including several syntheses by reduction, generation from LiNO, and by trapping of free HNO by deoxy myoglobin. In the latest funding period, we reinvestigated the trapping of HNO by Mb, which proceeds rapidly upon HNO release from the common precursors but is complicated by further reactivity. Time-course spectra of the trapping reactions were analyzed using SVD methods and global kinetic analysis.  We also determined the HNO dissociation rate by competitive trapping with CO, which was unexpectedly slow. This allowed us to report the binding affinity of HNO to deoxyMb, at 3.9 x 109 M-1, close to that of NO but orders of magnitude greater than those of O2 or CO.

We are now using similar methods for the reaction of O2 with HNO-Mb, is of relevance to Nitric Oxide Dioxygenase reactivity, a recently discovered capability of the oxyglobins to detoxify NO by conversion to nitrate. The mechanism of NOR is still quite controversial, but we have a unique starting material in stable HNO-globin adducts. We hypothesized that the reaction of HNO-Mb with O2 would generate an N-bound peroxynitrite. Indeed we observe short-lived intermediate very similar to that seen for the native NOD. Both formation and decomposition of the intermediate are affected by pH and O2 concentrations. Under a CO atmosphere, a different intermediate at 600 nm is observed, whose decomposition appears independent of O2; here the dominant products are nitrate and CO-Mb. We hypothesize these intermediates as porphyrin-bound peroxynitrito adducts.  The similarity of intermediates seen during these varied reactions may describe an intrinsic detoxifying mechanism.

As HNO is isoelectronic with O2, we hypothesize that it may react with metal complexes and proteins  that are known to bind or react with dioxygen.  Dioxygenases are non-heme enzymes that incorporate both atoms of dioxygen into a targeted substrate. Quercetin dioxygenase (QDO) catalyzes the oxidization of the flavonol quercetin (1) with dioxygen, cleaving the central heterocyclic ring and releasing CO. The QDO from B. subtilis is unusual in that it has been shown to be active with several divalent metal cofactors, but comparison of the catalytic activities suggest that Mn(II) is the preferred. In this past funding period, we reported that HNO can replace O2 in the activity of Mn-QDO, a, similarly cleaving the central ring and incorporating HNO-derived nitrogen regioselectively into the product. The enzyme Heme Oxygenase (HO) performs a similar dioxygenase reaction in which O2 reacts with a meso-hydroxyheme intermediate to generate verdoheme with concomitant release of CO. Others have modeled HO reactions using Fe(II)meso-hydroxy octaethylporphyrin. The substitution of HNO for O2 in analogous reactions, in which HNO generated in situ reacts with an Fe(II)meso-hydroxyporphyrin, form the monoazaporphyrin and release CO.

Broader Impact:  Personnel supported, 18 total: Postdoctoral researchers Ravi Kumar, Jagganath Buhyan. Graduate students: Tara Clover. Adrian Zapata, Michelle del’Homme, Jenny Han.

MS graduates: Tara Clover, Michelle del’Homme, 2014; PhD graduates: Adrian Zapata, 2015 (in process).

Undergraduate students: Azaan Ramani, Zach Sartor, Paul Derry, Emily Schmidt 2010; LaTraia Scott, Clayton Cothran, Kevin Byrd, Don Gray 2011; Regina Martin...

Products from this project 5 total: "Nitrosyl hydride (HNO) replaces dioxygen in nitroxygenase activity of manganese quercetin dioxygenase" Kumar, M.R.; Zapata, A.; Ramirez, A.J.; Bowen, S.K.; Francisco, W.A.; Farmer, P.J.
